communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1544055-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 98 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 947 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,011 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 2,360 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Reopening enforcement
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

For the following records holders/custodians:

Sandra Lay
Peabo Welcome
Argentina Rodriguez
Rohan Russell
Adam Gittlitz
Hai Le
Crystal Leckie
Kwabena Nuamah


For the following terms:

proactive, 311, mask, distancing, soap, sanitizer, cleaning, screening, reopening, HVAC, thermometer, barrier, central air, ventilation, filtration, COVID, airborne, aerosol, respirator, n95, infection, safety, droplets

Between January 1, 2020, and January 1, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

ALEXANDER RICCIO

communications.communication: Ok, that's two days from now, and three days from when you responded. Is there any reason why I may not receive documents by that date?

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Riccio:

A search for records responsive to your request returned well over 18 GB of data.  According to industry estimates, 1 GB of data can contain anywhere from 16,000 individual pages to over 60,000 pages, depending on the type of document involved.  DOHMH must review all records for applicable exemptions under FOIL prior to release. Could you please modify the terms of your request so that we can identify a reasonable number of potentially responsive records?

Many thanks,
Bernadette

proactive OR 311 OR mask OR distancing OR soap OR sanitizer OR cleaning OR screening OR reopening OR HVAC OR thermometer OR barrier OR "central air" OR ventilation OR filtration OR COVID OR airborne OR aerosol OR respirator OR n95 OR infection OR safety OR droplets(c:c)(date=2020-01-01..2022-01-01)

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
When I submitted my request on 12/15/2023, I specified the following 8 records holders:
Sandra Lay
Peabo Welcome
Argentina Rodriguez
Rohan Russell
Adam Gittlitz
Hai Le
Crystal Leckie
Kwabena Nuamah

If I read the above query correctly, it appears you have not narrowed to request to those individuals? If that is the case, please do so.

If you have 18 GB of data from a query involving those 8 records holders, please confirm as such and I will narrow.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Hi- yes this search was with the custodians you identified.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Thanks for being direct and quick - I've dealt with many state and local agencies which drag out this process for weeks.

Would it be possible for you to tell me how much data each search term generates? I could prioritize it that way.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: I’m sorry but we don’t have that capability.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
If running queries is cheap, easy and done in a few minutes or less, you could run a query like 
proactive (c:c)(date=2020-01-01..2022-01-01) 
(Count those results)
Then a query like 311 (c:c)(date=2020-01-01..2022-01-01) 
(Count those)
Etc...

Otherwise, I'll try and narrow it more tonight or tomorrow.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: Unfortunately, I cannot say that running each of these as separate searches is easy or done in a few minutes. I wish they were like Google searches, but they really are not. The system has to do heavy lifting depending on what is being searched for, and a search for over two years of email communications is a lot.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Ok, no fun, but not something either of us can fix. I kinda expect that one or two of those terms is responsible for the majority of the volume of records, but I'm hesitant to drop most of them. I'll start by removing several.

If I narrow to the following 16 terms is it more manageable?
mask OR
distancing OR
sanitizer OR
cleaning OR
reopening OR
HVAC OR
barrier OR
"central air" OR
ventilation OR
filtration OR
COVID OR
airborne OR
aerosol OR
respirator OR
n95 OR
droplets

communications.subject: Re: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: I can run this search, but based on my experience this is still going to return an extraordinary number of hits. Irrespective of job titles, as someone who worked at this agency during this time, key terms like "COVID" and "MASK"  were in so many emails.  Please let me know if you are open to modifying. If not, I will run the search.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: Hmph. The difficulty is that those are pretty central to what I'm looking for. If you just drop mask and COVID (so 14 terms) how many results?

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: This search returned 8.64 GB. It is still too broad, unfortunately.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
I think this shows that my earlier work has pointed me in the direction of the right records holders, and that we're making significant progress in narrowing it down (18GB -> 8GB cut it in half)

How about these nine terms:
distancing OR
sanitizer OR
reopening OR
"central air" OR
ventilation OR
filtration OR
airborne OR
n95 OR
droplets

I might be able to drop one or two more, but I've already removed most of the synonyms and coordinate terms I've seen in other documents across the public, federal, state, and even some local, realms...

If this still returns far too many records for the (understandably understaffed) FOIL office to review for release, let me know and I'll haggle with myself to try to further prioritize the relevant terms.

It would be difficult for me to choose which of the remaining to drop unless there'd be a way to later submit a request that returns only records that I had not yet been provided, I think? I know of at least one COVID FOI archive which has a similar problem, with dozens of redundant copies of records from separate requests - it's a real pain to make sense of my searches! 

I don't know what software the department has provided for you, but would you be able to later query for only records that were not returned by a query from this request? I imagine you'd be able to use a NOT operator to exclude these terms? Or something like it.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: My apologies for the delay. I am running the search now.  I should get back to you by tomorrow with the results, but please reach out after Wednesday if you have not heard back from me.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: Good morning- I ran this search, but it still returned 6.53 GB. This is still too large, unfortunately. Please note that using an “AND” connector may help.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Wow! Again, thanks for your patience in the matter. I must be hitting the nail on the head. I gotta think a bit before narrowing further.

Lemme get back to you in a few hours.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
I'm not totally sure if you're only searching emails or if you're doing some kind of eDiscovery search of all records. I hope it's the latter, but I am presuming that all 6 GB are emails, and the 1GB/16,000-60,000 pages ratio holds.

I don't want to use logical AND if I can avoid it, I want to leave that kind of thing to myself later when I have the final records.

I have a gut feeling "reopening" and "distancing" are catching a huge dragnet because so many things fell under the cognitive umbrella of "distancing".

If you drop those and search only for (sanitizer OR "central air" OR ventilation OR filtration OR airborne OR n95 OR droplets), does that get it down to something reasonable?

If *that* search is still massive, then a search for only (ventilation OR airborne OR n95 OR droplets)  is kinda acceptable if I bite my tongue, close my eyes, and stub my toe. 


I'd really rather not drop germs like "sanitizer" insofar as we went through several years of a predominantly airborne aerosol-inhalation-spread pandemic with authorities directing the general public to clean surfaces instead of the air.... So if you have the patience I'd really appreciate you trying the 7 term search first!!

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: I’m running the 7-word search, but I know based on experience this is still going to be huge.  Even the 4-word search will likely be huge.  The “AND” connector instead of “OR” could help.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: Hmmm. Let me know the results, keep me posted.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Good morning- this search returned over 4 GB. Unfortunately, it’s still too large. DOHMH needs to review the records for applicable exemptions prior to release.

sanitizer OR (c:s) "central air" OR (c:s) ventilation OR (c:s) filtration OR (c:s) airborne OR (c:s) n95 OR (c:s) droplets(c:c)(date=2020-01-01..2022-01-01)

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: Ok, hmm. Lemme get back to this today.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
It *is* difficult to bite the bullet and drop any of the remaining terms.

While I'm haggling over it today, if you just run a query for airborne OR n95, does that get it into reasonable territory?

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: That returned 1.57 GB. In my opinion, that is still too much. Let me know if there is something else that can be worked out or if you would like information on how to administratively appeal my determination.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: I'm still thinking about this - don't drop it yet! - I'll ask a few friends and colleagues for advice and try to get back to you Monday.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
I guess what I want is something like:


("proactive" OR "airborne" OR "n95" OR "soap" OR "sanitizer" OR "cleaning" OR "screening" OR "barrier" OR "safety" OR "HVAC" OR "thermometer" OR "central air" OR "ventilation" OR "filtration" OR "MERV" OR "aerosol" OR "respirator" OR "infection" OR "droplet" OR "mask") AND ("COVID" OR "COVID-19" OR "Coronavirus" OR "2019-nCoV" OR "Wuhan Coronavirus" OR "2019 NOVEL CORONAVIRUS" OR "reopening" OR "safety" OR "distancing")


...but I don't have any way to test purview KQL on my end.  Does that work and return a reasonable volume? or would I need to do something much more like this instead:

("airborne" OR "n95" OR "HVAC" OR "central air" OR "ventilation" OR "filtration" OR "MERV" OR "aerosol" OR "respirator") AND ("COVID" OR "COVID-19" OR "Coronavirus" OR "2019-nCoV" OR "Wuhan Coronavirus" OR "2019 NOVEL CORONAVIRUS" OR "reopening")

If the second (smaller) one is much smaller than the max you'd consider acceptable, I'd like to know how much the larger one returns too!

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: I am trying the second search first to see if that’s reasonable. I will let you know.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: This search returned 2.88 GBs.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Damnit.
At least I know I'm looking in the right place.


May I suggest we only use smaller files for the page estimation? It looks like you can use an operator like this to return only items smaller than a megabyte.
size:1..1048567

See:
"The second example returns messages from 1 through 1,048,567 bytes (1 MB) in size."
 https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/ediscovery-keyword-queries-and-search-conditions#:~:text=The%20second%20example%20returns%20messages%20from%201%20through%201%2C048%2C567%20bytes%20(1%20MB)%20in%20size.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: I have not used that before. You want me to try adding “size:1..1048567” to the search terms?

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: I mean, hey, no harm in trying it, it's in the documentation! Worst case is it just fails to parse the query. Best case is that all those giant powerpoints that got sent around without any image compression are excluded, and we get a better idea of how many pages of text actually need to be redacted.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: I will try running that search and let you know what happens.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: If you have not heard back from me by tomorrow afternoon, please ask for an update.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: Heh, ok! I appreciate the heads up!

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
I have good news. This search appears to be reasonable. However, DOHMH is working through a backlog of FOIL requests, and there are still hundreds of potentially responsive records to review in your request. Therefore, we will need until May 24, 2024 to respond.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks, and have a good weekend.

Bernadette

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Excellent news!

I think the final step here is to run the same query but with 
size:1048568..1074000000

And briefly look at the files that come back


I'd recommend downloading a copy of all the files to your local machine and use software like WinDirStat to examine the numbers, types, and sizes, of the files that are greater than 1 MiB here. I'm guessing that a small number of files are responsible for the vast majority of file space, and I would like to discuss using a different page estimation for those files.


If that's too slow, I also am the author of a very popular fork of that program that's manyfold faster, it's called altWinDirStat. I wrote after getting frustrated with the slowness of WinDirStat 😅. Your IT department may discourage installing altWinDirStat because I never bothered to sign the executable.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Good morning,

I’m not sure I understand. Are you asking to me to run the search again with size:1048568..1074000000?

The other search was at the cusp of reasonableness, so if this search will expand the results, it will likely not be reasonable.
Thanks,
Bernadette

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Kinda, yeah, but not exactly.

I'm suggesting you run the search again but only with that parameter returning larger files, with the intent of seeing how many files are of the kind that might fit the "1 GB of data can contain anywhere from 16,000 individual pages to over 60,000 pages" estimate. Using size:1048568..1074000000 returns all the results that are between about a megabyte and a gigabyte. I'm making an educated guess that a very small number of files are responsible for the majority of the on disk space.

I suspect that some files are very large on disk (like powerpoints with uncompressed images), but have very few pages that need to be reviewed. As an example, a scientist colleague of mine once had a powerpoint presentation that was more than a gigabyte in size, with something like only 50 slides. She'd included some videos that had never been compressed, which drastically inflated the file size.

I do not know exactly what features the city pays for (the licensing agreement with Microsoft is the subject of another ongoing FOIL request of mine!), but one possible option is you may be able to export a report to see more information about the documents the search returns:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/ediscovery-export-a-content-search-report

An alternative that I provided was to simply download a copy of the larger search results and spot check them to see if there are just a few files that account for the majority of the on-disk space. That's very easy with some common free software, but if you wish to do it manually, increasing the parameter to something like size:52430000..1074000000 should reduce the volume of files even further.

I'd expect that using size:1048568..1074000000 might return several hundred files, and size:52430000..1074000000 might return a few dozen. If you run the 50 MB-1GB search and the size of the responsive records are like 10GB, that means we've found the culprit! And I can ask you to either review the number of pages in that files when estimating the voluminousness of the request as a whole. If it's just a few powerpoints, neither of us have to worry about days  spent redacting 16,000 pages, it may only be a hundred.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Hi Alexander,

I appreciate your interest in the ediscovery process, and I hear what you are saying. I think for the purposes of FOIL, this really goes beyond what the statute requires.  I would propose we stick with the search that I identified as reasonable. In the alternative, I can provide you with instructions on how to submit an administrative appeal of this determination.

Please let me know.
Thanks,
Bernadette

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: That's ok then, let's go with the search you identified as reasonable.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Okay great. We have a backlog of requests we are working through, and based on the scope of this request, it will take us some time to review these records before they are released. I anticipate that you will receive a response to this request by May 24, 2024.

Thanks very much,
Bernadette

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
🤷‍♂️👍

Thanks! I'll be waiting eagerly!

communications.communication: Hello there. How many of the records have been processed so far?

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Hello there, we are approaching three missed agency-proposed records production dates. Will the August 16, 2024 agency-proposed records production date/deadline most recently proposed by the agency be met?

I would like to assume the agency is being forthright with me about meeting a date they propose, and have no knowledge of anything that they might be able to reasonably foresee preventing them from producing the requested and agreed upon records. I struggle to fathom how a pre-existing and ongoing backlog could surprise anybody by causing delays in records production - some agencies have abused this with me in a downright rude manner to delay requests more than a dozen times. 

I have no personal animus with any individual employed by the department - in a likely understaffed role - who is following routine agency procedures, and I presume they have no issue with me. We're all working with unfair systems run by people we have no contact with! Indeed, the records access officer I dealt with earlier was exceptionally helpful and more technically competent than the majority of records access officers that I've interacted with.

Over the years I have learned that such agency-proposed records production dates are more often missed than met, and it's no more likely the agency will meet the next date they propose than the one they've missed. On muckrock, this agency is a bit better than the average NYC agency, and returns records with an average of 113 days, so we're just on the edge of meeting this date! That's good news - I just want to rely on something better than crossed fingers.

I am pre-emptively appealing on grounds of constructive denial of records. I am asking the agency to provide guarantees that the August 16, 2024 agency-proposed records production date/deadline most recently proposed by the agency will be met, and if it cannot be met under current circumstances, that the agency shall either provide a date for which they will provide such records absent circumstances a reasonable person cannot reasonably forsee delaying production of records, or assign sufficient staff to meet the agency proposed records production date. 

I look forward to this appeal being moot upon production of records by the August 16, 2024 agency-proposed records production date.

communications.subject: Biscom DOHMH Delivery Data Servicestk@publishmeasap.com
communications.communication:
An account was requested on your behalf Samantha Bynoe by New York City Department of Health.



Your account has been created and you should receive an email with the credentials. Attached here is a small guide to help you along.



This service is used to send and/or receive files from/to an employee at the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.







DOHMH Data Delivery Service User Guide



This guide is an introduction to using the DOHMH Delivery Service (DDS) also known as Biscom.  DDS enables the secure delivery of files, documents and other electronic information while providing tracking and reporting capabilities.





DDS secure file transfer involves three simple steps:

1.   Create a package of files and deliver it to a pre-approved external email address.

2.   Recipients are notified of their secure delivery in an email message.

(Recipients must have an account in this system otherwise they will not be able to get files)

3.   Recipient signs into DDS, retrieves the package and downloads the file(s).





Definitions

Package: A file or collection of files uploaded to the DDS system.

Delivery: An email that links recipients to a package - packages that are created can be delivered.

Express Delivery: A way for Senders to upload files and deliver them in a single step (package creation and delivery are combined).

Sender: A user who has been approved to send files to one or more recipients.

Recipient: A authorized user who can receive files and reply to deliveries but cannot send their own files.





Logging in for the First time:



  1.  You will receive an email with the credentials from notify@a816-healthpsi.nyc.gov<mailto:notify@a816-healthpsi.nyc.gov> and the link that will take you to the login page.

That link is to always be used when using this system, so please bookmark it.



  1.  The email will look like the image below. Click on the link in the email to get the login page.

Enter your username and password.

Please note: Do not copy and paste the password, please type in each character



[cid:image001.jpg@01D91078.8B89BCC0]





  1.  Once logged in you will be immediately asked to change your password.

Once done you will be asked to re-login using the new password.



This is the policy for accounts:

If an account is inactive for 45 days, it will automatically be expired.

First inactivity warning is 14 days prior; Second inactivity warning is 7 days prior.

You must login at least once every 45 days to keep your account active.



This is the policy for passwords:

Password is valid for 90 days

Password Expiration warning is sent 7 days prior

Passwords must contain at least one of each



              The password must meet these requirements. It must have a least one from each a section:

                                           Uppercase letters:                               A - Z

Lowercase letters:                               a - z

Digits:                                                    0 - 9

Non-alphanumeric characters:     ~ , < , { , + ,  etc.

Password must be at minimum 8 characters (maximum is 50 characters)



  1.  Please setup your security questions which helps in case you forget your password.

You can do this by clicking on Personal settings on the top right of the screen then selecting Edit Profile

You will see the Fields for Password reset Question please enter your question and answer, then select update.



            Please note: You cannot reuse the same password you previously had.





Instructions for Sending Files:



To send one or more files, you must have the Sender role assigned to you. As a Sender, you will see the

 Express Delivery icon and link in the main menu.



[cid:image002.png@01D91078.8B89BCC0]





  1.  Click this link or icon to open the delivery screen.





[cid:image003.png@01D91078.8B89BCC0]



2.  Enter the email addresses of your recipients in the To field

3.   Enter a subject or topic in the Subject field.

4.   Drag and drop files into the files box or click the Add file button to open a file chooser dialog.

5.   Optional: enter a secure message.

6.   Optional: Click the Show options link to expand the delivery and enter an email notification message, and additional delivery options.

7.   Click the Send button to upload your files and send an email notification message to the recipients.





Replying to a Delivery:

Recipients can reply to a secure delivery they've received by clicking on the Show/Hide Reply Section link at the bottom of the delivery. A secure message and one or more files can be sent back to the original sender of the message.



Retrieving Files:

Recipients of secure deliveries receive a non-secure email in their email inbox. This email contains a notification message and an embedded hyperlink. Clicking the hyperlink will bring the recipient to the DDS application sign-in page, and once the recipient provides their username and password, the recipient will have access to their delivery.



Notice:

This secure data transfer system is the property of the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene and is intended for business purposes only. You have no right to privacy on the system, and all information and activity on the system may be monitored.  Any illegal or unauthorized use of the system may result in disciplinary action and/or civil or criminal penalties.

Your use of the system constitutes express consent to the above terms and conditions.









Regards, Tyler Bennett.

Sent from the New York City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene. This email and any files transmitted with it may contain confidential information and are intended solely for the use of the individual or entity to whom they are addressed. This footnote also confirms that this email message has been swept for the presence of computer viruses.

communications.subject: FOIL Control No. 2023FR02147 response
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Riccio:

My apologies for the delay.  The NYC Department of Health grants your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request with the above-referenced control number. Based on the size of the response file, records will be sent to you shortly via BISCOM. If you have issues with opening the file, please let me know.

Records have been withheld for the following reasons:

  1.  they are inter-agency or intra-agency materials pursuant to FOIL §87(2)(g); or
  2.  their disclosure would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy pursuant to FOIL §§ 87(2)(b) and 89(2)(b); or
  3.  they are exempt from disclosure pursuant to FOIL §87(2)(a); or
  4.  their disclosure would jeopardize the capacity of the Health Department to guarantee the security of its information technology assets pursuant to FOIL §87(2)(i).

In addition, redactions were made to records which were not responsive to your request.

You may file a written appeal of this determination within 30 days of the date of this message.  The appeal should be addressed to:
Chari Anhouse
Associate General Counsel and Records Access Appeals Officer
Email: recordsaccess@health.nyc.gov<mailto:recordsaccess@health.nyc.gov>

The notice of appeal should include the request control number, the date of this message, a description of the records that were the subject of the request, the specific legal grounds for your appeal, and the full name and email address of the original requester.

Sincerely,


Bernadette O'Donnell
Records Access Officer / Associate General Counsel
Office of the General Counsel
NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene - City of New York
42-09 28th St., Long Island City, NY 11101
Email: bodonnell1@health.nyc.gov<mailto:bodonnell1@health.nyc.gov> | nyc.gov/health<https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/index.page>

[cid:image001.png@01DAEFDD.83C94EB0]

communications.subject: Iowa Open Records Law Request: Agency Roster (Fort Madison Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Iowa Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Douglas PD Modified DESE Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, M. G. L.c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your police department.

Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement. DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”

I request the following public records, as defined in M. G. L.c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth):

1. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). I request an extract of the database to be provided as an electronic spreadsheet (.xls, .xlsx, .csv, .tsv, or .ods format). If such format is unavailable, we request the extract of the database to be provided in a searchable, machine-readable form, as per 950 CMR 32.04(5).” Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following descriptions of the data in each column. This may be provided as clear, descriptive column headers in the database extract or in a separate document:

a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement

b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement

c. Charge (or charges)

d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement

e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.

k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and

l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

m. Incident number or other unique identifier for each arrest or referral to law enforcement

n. Offender number or other unique identifier for each individual arrested or referred to law enforcement

2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

4. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until

the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.

5. Please also provide an unduplicated counts of referrals to law enforcement (as defined above) for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.

Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d).

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.

Sincerely,

Katherine Stathulis

J.D. Research Fellow

Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration k.stathulis@northeastern.edu

617-373-5862

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rylee Meints

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Presidential transition briefing materials (National Archives and Records Administration)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the primary briefing materials prepared in part or whole for purposes of the Presidential Transition Process, specifically any presentations created for, or delivered to, members of the Presidential Transition Team for the new administration.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dillon Bergin

communications.subject: Tennessee Public Records Act Request: Waivers and signage used in connection with art installation
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Tennessee Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. A copy of any (unsigned) waiver form presented or used in connection with the "The FL3TCH3R Exhibit" at the Reece Museum.

2. A copy of any photograph of any content warning presented or used in connection with the "The FL3TCH3R Exhibit" at the Reece Museum.

This request is limited to records generated on or after November 20, 2024. Please produce responsive records by email.

Please note that this request does not seek a search of records held by any faculty member or student.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kent Hoover, a citizen of Tennessee, in coordination with Adam Steinbaugh.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: NWLF 7.19.24
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

You are receiving this correspondence as a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552. I am requesting the following:

Copies of all Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) records, documents, and communications responsive to the New World Liberation Front (NWLF). The NWLF was a radical left-wing terrorist group that formed on or around November 23, 1973, with the bombing of a Pacific Gas and Electric utility substation in Cupertino, California. Over the next six years, the NWLF was credited with bombings throughout the United States; one instance, in 1976, involved members of the organization placing an explosive device on a windowsill at the home of then-San Francisco Supervisor (and later United States Senator) Dianne Feinstein. NWLF membership overlapped with another organization the FBI monitored in this same period: the Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA). SLA members Bill and Emily Harris claimed membership in the NWLF at the time of their arrests, in 1975.

The FBI, at various points during the 1970s, identified the NWLF as a subject of interest in ongoing investigations. Page six of a memorandum located in the FBI's HEARNAP records (dated October 11, 1974; HEARNAP Part 21, page 41) contains what appears to be a Bureau file number for the NWLF at its Los Angeles Field Office: "LOS ANGELES IS CONDUCTING INVESTIGATION REGARDING THE CASE CAPTIONED 'UNSUB; BOMBING OF SHERATON AIRPORT HOTEL, 9750 AIRPORT BOULEVARD, LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA, OCTOBER 5, 1974' EID - NEW WORLD LIBERATION FRONT, 00: LOS ANGELES, LOS ANGELES FILE 174-2103."

Additionally, a September 7, 1978 bulletin created by the FBI Terrorism Research Center outlined a detailed history and methodology of the NWLF, stating, in part: "[I]ncidents, over 70,  have ... occurred in Seattle, Washington; Rainier, Oregon; and Aurora, Colorado. Victims of NWLF attacks have included Federal, state and local governmental functions, diplomatic establishments, corporate facilities, and public utilities. Communiques claiming responsibility for the incidents state the actions were staged to protest against governmental policies and the intervention of the U.S. corporations into the internal affairs of foreign countries."

Both items indicate that the FBI created HQ and field office files for the NWLF in the course of investigations into terrorist attacks carried out by the organization. Therefore, I am requesting copies of all FBI records, documents, and communications responsive to the New World Liberation Front, aka the NWLF.

I am asking you waive any fees associated with this request. I am a member of the news media. My bylines, which include Unicorn Riot, Covert Action Magazine, and the Geopolitical Economy Report, can be found in both print and electronic publications, and I am sending this request in coordination with Muckrock, an award-winning and nationally-recognized news organization. Please take note of the Office of Management and Budget guidelines published March 27, 1987 (52 FR 10012) that include electronic publications and other nontraditional publishers as representatives of the news media.

A fee waiver is appropriate in situations where "disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government, and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester,” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(iii). This request would contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of government with regard to the FBI's handling of investigations into left-wing terrorism. The FBI has already made public records related to the kidnapping of Patricia Hearst in its HEARNAP collection. Contained in these records are numerous references to then NWLF, yet the FBI has not released any records on this group. Contemporaneous and postmortem accounts of the NWLF identify that Ms. Hearst interacted with NWLF members before her capture, thus the release of all NWLF records would contribute significantly to public understanding of the FBI's handling of the HEARNAP case.

Moreover, the NWLF carried out attacks on public officials and public services for almost a decade. Understanding how the FBI responded to these attacks is a matter of public interest.

This request is not being made for commercial purposes. All documents will be provided to the general public without charge.

In the event that there are fees, I am willing to pay up to $100. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

I look forward to your response within 20 working days, as the statute requires. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Sincerely,

Robert Skvarla, Jr.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Barry Romo
communications.communication:
Dear FBI:

This is a request for records under the Freedom of Information Act. 

RECORDS REQUESTED

I request all records related to Barry Louis Romo. Mr. Romo was born on 24 July 1947 in San Bernardino, California, USA and died on 1 May 2024.  

PROOF OF DEATH

I have attached Mr. Romo’s news obituary from the Washington Post, as reprinted in Stars and Stripes.

CROSS-REFERENCE SEARCH

In addition to your standard search, please also perform a cross-reference search of records related to the following organizations and events to see if they contain additional records related to Mr. Romo.

1. Vietnam Veterans Against the War
2. Iraq Veterans Against the War
3. United States Postal Service
4. Winter Soldier hearings

FEES

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. If you decide to charge me fees, please let me know in advance if those fees will exceed $25. 

FORM OF PRODUCTION

I would prefer that you fulfill this request electronically, producing responsive records via email attachment if available or on CD-ROM if not.

CONCLUSION

Thank you for responding to this request.

Sincerely,

Nicholas Marritz

I wanted to follow up on the following Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on May 8, 2024. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.  You had assigned it reference number #1634224-000.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1634224-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request

If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-0] please enter [1195846-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-1] please enter [1195846-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000
Case Type:
FOIPA
Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)

The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.

You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.


Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Our complex requests are further divided into small (51-250 pages), medium (251-500 pages), large (501-4,999), and extra-large (over 5,000 pages) sub-tracks.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing. Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process.
Currently, simple track cases average approximately 230 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Complex requests in the small processing track are currently averaging 1,085 days from the date of receipt for processing, those in the medium processing track are currently averaging 1,310 days, those in the large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,010 days, and those in the extra-large track are averaging 2,370 days  .


Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Mezuzah at Naval Observatory
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

On on Oct. 7 the Vice President and Second Gentleman installed a mezuzah on the doorpost of Number One Observatory Circle. This event was reported by the Forward (https://forward.com/fast-forward/478353/harris-and-emhoff-place-mezuzah-on-doorpost-of-vice-presidents-residence/) and by the Second Gentleman himself (https://twitter.com/SecondGentleman/status/1461362649841627159)

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any communications between the office of the Vice President or the Second Gentleman and those at the Navy responsible for the upkeep of Number One Observatory Circle about this event, or about the permissibility of affixing an object to Number One Observatory Circle's doors.

Please limit this request to the period between April 7, 2021 and October 10, 2021.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Russel Neiss

The assigned FOIA request tracking number, DON-NAVY-2022-001711, remains the same throughout the document review process and regardless of the agency reviewing responsive documents. 
The documents collected in response to your FOIA request were sent on 12/01/2021 to the Office of the Secretary of Defense's (OSD) FOIA Program Office for mandatory review.  Review of the documents by the OSD FOIA office is mandatory due to the high visibility, sensitive nature of the documents and any potential for national security content.  As of 07/27/2022, the documents remian in the possesion of the OSD FOIA office for completion of its mandatory review.  Upon completion, the documents will be routed back to the Commander Navy Installations Command FOIA program office to be processed for release to you. 
Unfortunately, our office is not able to give you an estimated completion date of the OSD FOIA review at this time.  Upon receipt of the documents in our office from the OSD FOIA office, they will be processed for release to you as expeditiously as possible.  Your continued patience is requested and appreciated as the review process continues forward. 
Due to lengthiness of the mandatory OSD review process, you are advised you have the option of withdrawing your FOIA request. The CNIC FOIA Program office IS NOT instructing or recommending you withdraw your request but only informing you of your option to do so.  If you desire to withdraw your FOIA request, please do so in writing via a reply to this correspondence within 30 days. 
Our office will continue to keep you informed of the status of your request. 
Thank you.

Patricia Williams-Butler

communications.subject: DON-NAVY-2022-001711 Request - Status Update 10/17/2022
communications.communication:
Good Day, Mr. Neiss - 
The documents collected in response to your FOIA request were sent on 12/01/2021 to the Office of the Secretary of Defense's (OSD) FOIA program office for mandatory review.  Review of the documents by the OSD FOIA office is mandatory due to the high visibility, sensitive nature of the documents and any potential for national security content.  As of 10/17/2022, the documents are still  in the possesion of the OSD FOIA office for mandatory review.  Upon completion, the documents will be routed back to the Commander Navy Installations Command FOIA program office to be processed for release to you. 
Unfortunately, our office is not able to give you an estimated completion date of the OSD FOIA review at this time.  Upon receipt of the documents in our office from the OSD FOIA office, they will be processed for release to you as expeditiously as possible.  Your continued patience is requested and appreciated as the review process continues forward.   I will contact you when I have more info concerning the completion of the OSD FOIA review process. 
Please do not hesitate to contact our office if you have any questions or concerns. 
Thank you. 
Respectfully, 
Patricia Williams-Butler 
FOIA Coordinator Commander Navy Installations Command 
Office of General Counsel 
Washington Navy Yard, DC

communications.subject: DON-NAVY-2022-001711
communications.communication:
Good afternoon Mr. Neiss,

 

I am the Temporary FOIA Coordinator at Commander, Navy Installations Command
(CNIC). I am writing regarding your FOIA request DON-NAVY-2022-001711. 

 

I apologize for the delay, but please know that your request is still being
reviewed, and we will continue to diligently process your request. However,
in case anything has changed and if you are no longer interested in pursuing
this request, please kindly let me know. 

 

Should you have any questions or concerns, or if you wish to inquire about
an update, please do not hesitate to contact me directly at the email
address below. 

 

V/R,

 

Elizabeth Retter

LCDR, JAGC, USNR

Temporary FOIA Coordinator

Commander, Navy Installations Command

Email:   <mailto:elizabeth.v.retter.mil@us.navy.mil>
elizabeth.v.retter.mil@us.navy.mil

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #DON-NAVY-2022-001711
communications.communication:
Good evening Mr. Neiss,



Thank you for forwarding this. Unfortunately, from what I can see, your 
requested documents are still in the possession of the OSD FOIA office for 
mandatory review.  The same day I reached out to you, I also reached out to 
the Department of the Navy Office of the Chief of Naval Operations 
FOIA/Privacy Act Program (DNS 36), in order to request an update about your 
case. I have not heard back yet.



If you would like to contact them directly, their email address is: 
usn.ncr.dns.mbx.don-foia-pa@us.navy.mil 
<mailto:usn.ncr.dns.mbx.don-foia-pa@us.navy.mil> . Their phone number is 
202-685-0412.  Please note that they do not hold your records (OSD does) but 
they should be able to get an update from OSD for you.



I will also let you know as soon as I hear back from them.



There is not much CNIC can do while the records are with OSD, but once we 
receive your records from OSD, we will process them as expeditiously as 
possible.



In the meantime, please do not hesitate to contact me, and thank you for your 
patience in this process.



V/R,



Elizabeth Retter

LCDR, JAGC, USNR

Temporary FOIA Coordinator

Commander, Navy Installations Command

Email:   <mailto:elizabeth.v.retter.mil@us.navy.mil> 
elizabeth.v.retter.mil@us.navy.mil

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #DON-NAVY-2022-001711
communications.communication:

CNIC collected and sent the responsive records to the OSD FOIA office for mandatory review on 12/01/2021 where they have apparently languished since.

Repeated attempts to solicit an update from OSD have been unsuccessful. 

I was hopeful that you would be able to get an update on the OSD FOIA review process for me.

Thank you so much for your time and attention.

Please let me know if you require any additional information.

Best,
Russel Neiss

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Electronic Communications Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Electronic communications (to include e-mail, “Classdojo” messages, or any other form of electronic messages) between Paige Locke (paigeorama707@gmail.com and  paigelocke707@gmail.com) and Brevard Public Schools employee Ashley Tubbs (Tubbs.Ashley@brevardschools.org) for the period of 10/1/2022 until date of production

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Michael Locke

Dear Michael Locke,
We have received your public records request.

Your request will be processed in accordance with the Florida Public Records Law.

Please be advised there are potentially fees to cover the cost of reproduction, including copier expenses, supplies and staff time associated with all requests.  You will be advised as soon as possible regarding estimated costs.  Payment will be due in advance by check or money order made payable to the School Board of Brevard County.  If the actual cost is more than the estimate, your records will be released when payment in full has been received.  If the actual cost is less than the estimate, a check for reimbursement will be requested and mailed to you.

PLEASE NOTE: Not all completed public records are in a digitized format.  To receive a digitized version of a redacted record may require additional time and resources, resulting in additional expense.

You will be notified if records are exempt from public disclosure.  Under public records laws, the district is not obliged to create a new document or records in response to a request for public records.  Likewise, the district will not acquire computer software for the sole purpose of providing access or delivery of public records that are accessible by other means.

If you have any questions, please contact me at recordsrequest@brevardschools.org<mailto:recordsrequest@brevardschools.org>.

Holly Christmas

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request #24-676
communications.communication:
Thank you for your response. To clarify, I submitted this request in my personal capacity as a parent, not on behalf of MuckRock or for any commercial purpose. Under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA), as a parent I have a right to access my child's educational records, which includes communications between school staff that relate to my child.

Please let me know if you need any additional information from me to process this request, such as a copy of my ID or custody paperwork demonstrating my parental rights. I would be happy to provide that documentation. If there are any fees associated with searching for or copying these records, please inform me before fulfilling my request.

I understand you must comply with FERPA, but that law also ensures parental access to student records, with limited exceptions. FERPA requires redacting personally identifiable information about other students, but communications relating to my child should be provided to me, with appropriate redactions if needed.

If any responsive records are located, I would prefer to receive them electronically via email if possible, to avoid copying costs. If records are withheld or redacted, please cite the specific statutory exemption that forms the basis for the denial and advise me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Thank you in advance for your assistance with my request. Please let me know if you have any questions or need further information from me.

Sincerely,
Michael Locke

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request #24-676
communications.communication:
Given your role in the Office of Legal Services, I’m seeking clarification regarding district policy on recommending school-based counseling for a student who, according to official school records, displays no behavioral or academic concerns in school and is described as a role model to her peers.

As a parent, I am curious about how such a recommendation aligns with district procedures, particularly in a Title 1 school setting where resources are often allocated based on immediate, school-related needs. Specifically, I’d appreciate insight into:

	1.	District Procedures and Resource Allocation: What is the district’s stance on using Title 1 resources, like school-based counseling, for students who do not display in-school issues? How is this type of intervention typically justified and documented in such cases?
	2.  Compliance and Liability: Could recommending school-based counseling under these circumstances pose any compliance or liability concerns for the district, particularly if the recommendation is based on observations outside of the school environment?

Thank you for your time and assistance in clarifying the district’s policy on these matters. I look forward to your guidance on how this aligns with established procedures and legal obligations.

Best regards,
Michael Locke

files.source: Michael Locke

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request #24-676
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Christmas,

I am writing to request information pursuant to the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA), 20 U.S.C. § 1232g, regarding a specific conference note dated March 7, 2024, associated with my child, Rowen Locke, who attends Sabal Elementary School.

The document in question pertains to a parent-requested meeting attended by Paige Locke, Ashley Tubbs (now Mrs. Woltman), and Debra Pollard. While the note reflects the meeting date of March 7, 2024, it does not indicate the date and time when the note was actually created or entered into the school’s record-keeping system.

I was informed of this meeting only after it had occurred and subsequently spoke with Ms. Tubbs (now Mrs. Woltman) via ClassDojo. In that conversation, I expressed my views on the subjects discussed during the meeting; however, these views were not reflected in the conference note. To ensure complete transparency and accuracy in my child’s educational records, I am requesting the following under FERPA:

	1.	Initial Entry Date and Time: Documentation or metadata showing when the March 7, 2024, conference note was first entered or saved in your electronic records system.
	2.	Audit Trail: An audit log or record of access, including any modifications, views, or retrievals of this document, along with the associated dates and times. This information will help verify when and by whom the document has been accessed or modified within the school’s system.
	3.	Explanation of Record Creation Process: Any policies or procedures relating to how records like conference notes are entered, saved, and generated from your system, specifically addressing any delays between the meeting date and the creation date of the document.

As a parent with rights to review and access my child’s educational records under FERPA, I am seeking this information to verify the accuracy and integrity of the documentation in Rowen’s records. I would appreciate a prompt response within the time frame required under FERPA regulations, and I am open to receiving these records in electronic format via email.

If there are any fees associated with providing these records, please inform me in advance. Should you require further clarification or additional information to process this request, feel free to contact me at the phone number or email address provided above.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your response.

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request #24-676
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Christmas,
Pursuant to my records request #24-676, I am attaching an email chain regarding a March 7, 2024 Zoom meeting concerning Rowen Locke. The chain includes:

March 4, 2024 11:48 AM email from Paige Locke to Mrs. Tubbs
March 4, 2024 12:43 PM response from Mrs. Tubbs
March 4, 2024 6:48 PM confirmation from Paige Locke

Could you please confirm whether this is a true and accurate copy of the educational record maintained by Brevard Public Schools?
Thank you for your assistance.
Best regards,
Michael Locke

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request Locke-PRR-#25-389
communications.communication:
Good Morning,

We have received your records request.

Your request will be processed in accordance with the Florida Public Records Law.

Please be aware The School Board of Brevard County, Florida is not a covered entity under HIPAA and therefore Directive Letter/HITECH Act.42 is not applicable. The School Board of Brevard County as a political subdivision of the State of Florida, is required to comply with Florida Statutes in response to its responsibility to comply with requests for public records, particularly, Section 119.07, Florida Statutes, titled Inspection and copying for records; photographing public records: fees: exemptions.

Please be advised there are potentially fees to cover the cost of reproduction, including copier expenses, supplies and staff time associated with all requests.  You will be advised as soon as possible regarding estimated costs.  Payment will be due in advance by check or money order made payable to the School Board of Brevard County.  If the actual cost is more than the estimate, your records will be released when payment in full has been received.  If the actual cost is less than the estimate, a check for reimbursement will be requested and mailed to you.

PLEASE NOTE: Not all completed records are in a digitized format.  To receive a digitized version of a redacted record may require additional time and resources, resulting in additional expense.

You will be notified if records are exempt from disclosure.  Under public records laws, the district is not obliged to create a new document or records in response to a request for public records.  Likewise, the district will not acquire computer software for the sole purpose of providing access or delivery of records that are accessible by other means.

If you have any questions, please contact me at recordsrequest@brevardschools.org<mailto:recordsrequest@brevardschools.org>.
Holly Christmas
Florida Certified Records Manager
Office of Legal Services
Brevard County Public Schools
2700 Judge Fran Jamieson Way
Viera, FL  32940
321 633-1000 x11453
[BPSLogoColor]
You can’t change the past, but you can ruin the present by worrying about the future.

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Agency Roster (Orlando Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Traffic Stop Records (Department of Transportation)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Public Records Law, G.L., c. 66, § 10, I hereby request the following records:

all data, including statistical information, collected from any Massachusetts Uniform Citation (“MUC”) issued in the Commonwealth between January 1, 2021 and May 2024.

Some important fields may include: 

City of Boston Employee ID (6 digit ID)
Employee first name
Employee last name
Employee middle name
Badge Number
Rank
District/Taskforce
Date of Stop
Time of Stop
Location of stop
Latitude/longitude
Race of driver
Gender of driver
Age of driver
If search occurred
If contraband was found,

I also request a waiver of all fees for this request, as disclosure of the requested information to me is in the public interest and will contribute to the public’s understanding of operations and activities of the government. This request is being made for research conducted by Spark! at Boston University and will not be used for commercial use.

I expect the request to be filled in an electronically-accessible format, including for screen readers, excel, or CSV. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. We understand that the data may be large in size, so feel free to send it over in year or half-year increments.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. If you believe any of this information to be exempt, I ask you to please cite the specific portion of the law on which you rely. I also ask you to please redact any information you believe to be exempt and disclose the rest. If you need to discuss this request, I can be reached at 617-358-8514.

Sincerely,
Boston University SPARK!
